headline: French Fried Potatoes
description: The best potatoes for French fries are soaked in a brine of sugar and water which allows them to fry up golden and crispy outside and soft inside.
name: French Fried Potatoes
recipeIngredient: 2 large russet potatoes - peeled, and sliced into 1/4 inch strips

recipeInstructions.text: Stir together warm water and sugar in a medium bowl. Soak potatoes in water mixture for 15 minutes. Remove potatoes from water and dry thoroughly on paper towels.
Heat oil in a deep-fryer to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Cook potatoes in hot oil until golden, 5 to 6 minutes. Drain on paper towels and season with salt.

review.reviewBody: This worked perfectly thank you.
I tried another recipe before and it didn't work out, but this one my kids loved it. They fried so well and tasted good even without the salt on them.
IT'S Yum, thanks for that
So yummy! Nice and crisp! Made them last week. I gotta make these for my son who was away last week.
Nice and crispy and you avoid having to fry them twice.

To add to the ocment about frying twice, one way to prep and be ready on the day is to follow the recipe up to the first frying, then fry for around 6 or 7 minutes at 350 (note the oil temperature will plunge, so keep the burner on maximum). Then take them out and blot dry as soon as you can. Freeze. When you want to make the fries heat oil to 375 degrees, then pour in the frozen fries (they'll bubble a lot, but you've already driven off most of the water, so it won't be too bad). 6 or 7 minutes later, perfect fires. And by prepping, the final stage takes such a short time.
This is a perfect and simple way to make fries like Mom did for us as kids - none of that fancy pub fry topping - just a nice fry to go alongside a burger or sandwich.
Amazing. Great fries now two times!

Been on a quest for the perfect, easily attainable home French fry recipe for so long. I have a job, I have kids, I have commitments. I don’t have time for hours of soaking, drying, frying at home temp, reheating oil, frying again..... there has to be a better way. This is it! The sugar water concoction seems to do the trick. These came out absolutely perfect and crispy with only ONE trip through the fryer. Perfection!
These were amazing! I followed the recipe exactly except that I doubled it. I have a big crew to feed.
These French fries are so good. My husband and kids loved them. They taste just like In-N-Out’s French fries.
My 1st time made french fries and I love it. simple recipe and easy to cook! Thank you.
These fries turned out amazingly good. Looking forward to making them again.

I followed the recipe, and cooked it the time specified. I was using my deep fryer outside, and unfortunately, it was not very well lit area. I didn't want the fries overcooked, so brought them in after 5-1/2 minutes. They were fully cooked through, but not at all crispy. My fault for not getting a better light. I will use this recipe again, but adjust cooking time.
Avocado oil
Avocado oil excellent results
Veryyyyy so goooodddddd!!!!!!!!
This is a great recipe. I will be making these again soon.
It's a great quick to make fries, when your short on time. My family loved it.
My fries turned out great on the first try
Maybe turned out pretty good,I added season salt for an extra kick! Although, not super Krispy my family loved them!!
I didn't see the difference between the sugar water and nothing at all.
What a treat! Yes, I'll make it again. I plan on making it for the grandchildren soon. I made the potato chip recipe for them and they always ask me if I am going to make it again.
Recipe was great. I deep fried them at 360 for 5 minutes. Should have done six minutes for a crispier fry.
Very good! Did rounds instead of slices. Will definitely be trying again, and with sweet potatoes and yams, as well!
Too sweet We did not care for this recipe.
These are some of the best french fries I've had whether home made or restaurant.
Followed all directions and our fries came out tasty with little crispiness. Next time will leave in for longer than direction time frame. Will definitely make again!
we did our usual twice fry method and i'm sad to say that this really didn't make much of a difference for us
Didn't need that much oil for frying. Needed to cook longer than 5-6 minutes but maybe the oil just hadn't gotten quite up to temperature yet.

Previously I had mediocre results with my french fries. Then I saw the curing in sugar instead of vinegar. Then I read the McDonald's recipe and wasn't crazy about the addition of corn syrup on top of the sugar. I read this recipe and wasn't surprised that users weren't getting stellar results from the absence of blanching. So, going along with Cindy Chaney's knowledge and my failures I used only enough hot water to completely dissolve the sugar then added the rest cold water and set in the fridge for the 15 minutes. Removed and patted dry and returned to the fridge while my oil heated to 375. I then blanched the potatoes for exactly 2 minutes. Removed and patted dry. During that time my fryer was able to recover it's 375 temp so that 6 more minutes made perfect, restaurant style french fries. And didn't taste the sugar at all! I gave this recipe 5 stars because with mine and Cindy's knowledge of french making, I've finally come up with a recipe that makes stiff fries without having to over cook them to get restaurant texture french fries.
Not much changes. Just that I used tissue I instead of paper towel, I don't know if it's the same but all the same it turned out great just like what I eat at the KFC. Thanks a lot

This recipe is excellent. I'd like to add that you can substitute salt or soda for the sugar. What actually transpires when you soak the potatoes in the sugar/salt/soda water is that the water is more dense with the additive. Water tends to move from an area of less concentration to an area of greater concentration. In other words, the water is somewhat leeched out of the potatoes to try to equate the amount of water between the two. When fried, that will make the potatoes crispier because there is less water.
Nice, golden, & yummy fries!
one word to describe, amazing! thank you for sharing this recipe for perfect fries. now my husband says mine are the best!
The fries were not crispy. Flavor not good. Will not make again

Great technique! My fries came out more crispy after soaking in sugar water for 15 mins. I suggest spin in salad spinner then use paper towels to remove excess water. Also for extra crunch I fry for 2 mins then remove, let cool for 10 mins then fry second time like others have suggested. I also use the deep fryer for even cooking.

These were great!! I didn't have a deep fritter so i used a deep stock pot, before adding the pre soaked fries to the pour i seasoned them with onion powder and accent salt,i also left the skin on because i just love the taste of thick steak fries and potato skins.
I have tried to make French fries and potato chips before and they never turned out right. These were amazing.
I used gold potatoes instead cause that's what I had... But followed everything else as it is.. And they came out really good. My kids liked them also.. That says a lot;)

My family loved them!
The soaking in the sugar solution did wonders, but I borrowed Chef John's tip and fried them twice, first to soften, then a second time to make them crisp. Lovely, crispy, delicious.
Definitely one for the ages!

Dee..Lish...Us!!!!!
I made a batch of these to try them out before making them for dinner. I cut mine into Cottage Fries though. I left a few out after the first fry to try the double fry. The first ones were soo good though. Can't wait to try the second ones and will definitely be making these for dinner tonight!!
Awesome! My nieces were missing their mother's fries (she passed away last year) and they said it was delicious! I agree! Thanks so much for posting!
WOW. These fries are incredible. The 2 minute blanching is one of the keys to make them perfect.
This recipe is perfect! The only thing that I changed is I cut my potatoes Julianne style. They turned out deliciously crispy, almost just like at McDonald's! My hubby loved them too.
I followed the directions and they're the best fries I've ever had. The whole family loved them!!

Amazing fries!!!! No need to go out and get fast food fries after you've tried this recipe. I tried it today. I went with the cold water 1/3 cup sugar instead of the warm and had the time to let them soak for 2 hours. I cooked them in two batches, the first was cooked twice around 2 1/2 min each time and the second was cooked 5 min straight up. The first batch came out extremely crisp, had that perfect light brown color and tasted fantastic, the 2nd batch came out a bit lighter but were just as good, I had no preferences between the two.. I WILL make these again and again and keep them as a staple in my household for years to come. Thank you for this recipe :)
Made this with sloppy joes... perfect combination

Such great fries! Have to get the oil hot hot hot! Then they will crisp up nicely! I blanch mine in the boiling sugar water first, and will try the second fry next time. It might be great to fry a big batch, then freeze what we don't need for the night and have our own frozen fries for quick meals.

It worked for what I needed - something to fill a french fry craving when there were no frozen ones in the house. However, they were kind of soggy. They tasted good, if a little oddly sweet, but they seemed to get soggier the longer they cooked. I may try the ice cubes in the water, or the hot oil blanching suggested by others if I try this again.
Surprising how wonderful these fries are! I highly recommend it and do not skip the sugar soak - I agree with other chef it is the difference in the crispiness

My 12 year old daughter made these and she loved them.
Thank you for this great recipe.

Dragged out the old Frydaddy the wife hasn't used in years. Perfection on the first try! Combined a couple tips from other reviewers to make the process go smooth and easy. Tossed the potatoes in the water and put the bowl in the refrig for about forty minutes and used a salad spinner to save on paper towels. Drained the finished product on a paper towels on top of newspaper. Thank you Lorelei.
The kids loved these fries. I thought they could have been slightly crispier. But all in all I'm saving this one. I followed the directions exact also.
Not crunchy at all and so greasy :(
its kinda soggy so lightly fry the fries then dip in a seasoned batter and fry till golden ! yumm~
This is THE way to make french fries! I'm glad I found this cuz I got sick of serving soggy homemade fries.

Delicious. I had to make fries for more than 2 people so I doubled everything. Water sugar and potatoes. I soaked the potatoes for about 2 hours and then drained them and dried them a bit with a towel. I went with the hint of blanching them for a few minutes and then pulled them out of the oil. Once all the batches were done I could quickly get them crispy and brown. This took about 3 to 5 minutes per batch for the amount I Deep fried. They were so good my husband said that if there had been a five gallon pail full he would have still ate everything there. Thanks for sharing this recipe. I agree With another poster that the warm water is used to dissolve the sugar. I did this with one cup of warm water and then added the rest of the water as cold. I also put a layer of ice cubes over the potatoes as they were soaking. Then when it was time to take them out they were nice and cold.

These fries rock!! I had planned on making them last night, but after peeling, cutting and soaking in the sugar bath-our dining plans changed. So.... they held in the sugar bath in the fridge till tonight. Patted them dry, fried them up, salted them and polished them all off! I even greatly increased the amounts of potatoes but my family of 5 did not even leave a spud rubble! I am a believer in the sugar bath now! Thanks for a great recipe! (Oh, and I cut them quite thick-they were better than the county fair fries!) Yum!
1st time making homemade french fries and they turned out great! Love the recipe, thanks for sharing!!
Nice and Crispy!

I haven't exactly used this recipe but it's just like the one my Mom passed down to me 40 years ago and with a little tweaking I made it my own and it's just like this one so I know this is worth 5 stars. ?? I find using vegetable oil like this recipe calls for is the best. I use it too. It's light and not heavy like olive oils and others can be. I also use a Westmark Potato Slicer and set it to make the fries thin like Mc Donald's fries except I leave the potato peel on. Mc Donald's removes the peel. The real secret is the sugar water. Trust me you will not get fries that taste sweet! Not in the least bit! In my 40 years of making them I have yet to be able to put my finger on exactly what the sugar does but I think it helps keep the fries light and not oily, fry up crisp and taste absolutely perfect! This recipe is worth all 5 stars and more!
My husband loved them...he said they remind him on In and Out Burger French Fries.

The sugar makes the difference, but if you really want to make the best fries, fry them in beef tallow. That's what made MacDonald's fries taste so special before they caved in to extremists in 1990. Lard is almost as good and readily available.
Followed instructions exactly; perfect !! Everyone loved them and all were gone in a few minutes. Thanks for posting.
Super bummed. Very soggy. We choked them down because we hate waste. So disappointed.

I have not tried this, but in the 60's I was a fry cooker at McDonalds. We would cut, wash, (3 times) and then blanch them. (325 degrees) After they were blanched, we would let them cool, then refry them at 375 degrees til golden brown. The secret was in washing them, and drying them. The bottom of our sinks were covered with starch, and thats what we tried to get rid of. After three washes, there was little or no starch left.

I did the quick fry and then a second fry. Delicious. My husband and I both thought they were as good as Five Guys or better. I used red potatoes. My mother always soaked her french fries in ice water before frying to get them crispy. The sugar water lends a sweet flavor to go with lightly salted fries.
awesome
I really liked the soaking in sugar water. I was able to cut & prepare these way ahead of time. And when fried, they came out crispy & good. I added some seasoning when they came out of fryer.
Terrific. Customize seasoning to preference. I like to add chili powder and seasoning salt for something with a burst. But still great as written.
Great recipe. Only changes I made were cooking canola oil on a skillet medium-high. YUM!
The best fries I've ever had. I've tried making my own in the past on numerous occasions and they've never been as crisp as these. Yum yum!

This is my go to recipe for homemade french fries. I usually soak in sugar water for at least 1/2 an hour or overnight in refrigerator (water should be clear) and then drain and absorb as much of the water on a reusable drying mat and allow to dry as much as possible. I keep one just for these fries. Always do a long fry (about 6-10 minutes depending on how thick your potatoes are cut- we prefer large wedges) and then just before you're ready to serve, refry till golden brown, about 2 minutes. not sure if it matters whether you do long or short fry first, but the long fry first makes most sense if you're doing fish AND chips. I've done both with great results. Prefrying the potatoes ahead of time helps speed up dinner time. Perfect and delicious every time! I cook for 5 hungry kids so anything I can do ahead helps. 
To save paper towel, line a large platter with folded newspaper under a of couple of pieces of paper towel.
Also, a large cast iron pot for frying is best. You can sustain the temperature of the oil better and fry larger and fewer batches. 

For those wondering what to do with the leftover oil, let it cool, strain or pour into a covered container and store in the fridge for your next time you need to deep fry something. I find reused oil actually makes the food taste better and it browns the food better as well. I add fresh oil to top up because you will lose some each time you fry and you have to get rid of the brown bits which causes the oil to go rancid.
I soaked mine in cold water to remove the starch. Fried twice (first to blanch, then to crisp) and skipped the sugar solution. Also, I only used 1 cup of vegetable oil. They turned out wonderfully!

This is the secret to the perfect french fry.

1)soak overnight in cold water with 2 tablespoons white sugar.
2)Dry with paper towel
3)blanch in vegetable oil with burner on medium until just before they turn brown - then remove to paper towel.
4)Turn burners to high and cook until fries reach your desired brown hue.
5)Enjoy the deliciousness

real crispy on the outside and tender on the inside.i left the skin on and the wedges with the most skin on them tasted really great! i followed the suggestions of the other reviewers and soaked in cold water for a few minutes before frying.

thank you!

I wanted this to work so badly. Recipe as written did not give me crunchy french fries. Recipe as modified by others (2 minutes in oil, then remove, then the final 5 minutes or so) also did not give me the french fry of my dreams. Could be my potatoes, could be operator error, not sure. I'll try again.
These were good. somewhat tastier than regular cut potatoes deep fried. i will probably make these again. I made two batches one regular and one with nacho cheese.

My difference, I double fried mine, like Paula does, and I see from the reviews that Alton does also (I only recently started watching him) I also saw a tip in one of the reviews to use the salad spinner to drain the water. How clever! I forget about that little spinning wonder sometimes.
I fried them twice as other reviewers suggested and it worked great. My husband's comment was "these are impressive." Thanks for all the good tips!

If you are looking for fries that taste like the street vendors or a steak sandwich place these are it. They are slightly crispy on the outside but very soft on the inside. Make sure to use the large "russet" potatoes as suggested. They are the best for baked potatoes and fries. The fries are actually quite easy to make to. I just fried them in my mini deep fryer one batch at a time. The timing is very precise to about 5-6 minutes per batch. Make sure to have a salad or something else, because these are hard to quit eating.
I have made these several times and they taste great. Fresh french fries are much better than anything at McDonalds! The kids love them!

Very good--I have been using this sugar/water formula since trying this. Like some other reviewers, I also fry twice because that is how I remember my grandmother and aunt making fries when I was young.
These french fries taste just like New York Fries!! I like to spice them up with a little bit of paprika and cumin rather than salt! So yummy! I have made these over and over again!
My family loved these. Surprised that there is no sugary taste. Crisp on the outside. This is how french fries are done. Thanks Lorelei
Baked the fries at 350 for about 45 mins. sprayed with pam and sprinkled with salt.
Yummy! Easy to make and it was delicious!
Turned out lovely, I fried twice as others have stated (Alton Brown style).

I have tried the sugar water method before, did not notice any difference than just using cold water. I am a fan of Good Eats, and agree with Alton Brown's method of twice frying. I also use his method of starch conversion for hashbrowns. Placing them in a cold environment (in the fridge) over night. I still soak my fries, but i use salt water , then rinse, and a finally use a salad spinner to help dry them. 

I then use my fryer at 320F and fry for 5 minutes, drain on paper towels, and cool until close to room temperature. Then i fry again at 350F until golden and crisp.
OMG!! This are sooooo amazing!!!! And soooooo addictive i just finshed making them and already half gone!!
Very good but take a lot of time.

Very pleased with this recipe. Simple and delicious. Imparts a slightly sweet taste to fries. Will definitely make again. 
I made a larger batch and used less oil by frying in deep non-stick skillet rather than deep fryer.
The sugar water makes this recipe complete. Thanks for the tip.
Awesome! The key is the cold water and sugar, and the double frying like other reviewers suggested! I love making these!!!
Love it with my fish and chips!!!
They were not very crunchy...
OMG! SO GOOD!

Thse fries turned out terrible for me. I do better off when I don't soak the potatoes. Maybe I didn't use enough sugar in the water but I will not be trying these again. The time it takes for the potatoes to sit is the deterrent for me. My 4yr who adores fries wouldn't eat them.
